slide.paragraphs: How would we compute an inverse? And just when is a matrix invertible, and when is it not? Writing a putative inverse with $n^{2}$ unknowns and solving the resultant $n^{2}$ equations is one approach. Applying this approach to $2\times 2$ matrices can get us somewhere, so just for fun, let us do it.

statement.title: Computing the Inverse of a Nonsingular Matrix
Computing the Inverse of a Nonsingular Matrix
statement.paragraphs: Suppose $A$ is a nonsingular square matrix of size $n$. Create the $n\times 2n$ matrix $M$ by placing the $n\times n$ identity matrix $I_{n}$ to the right of the matrix $A$. Let $N$ be a matrix that is row-equivalent to $M$ and in reduced row-echelon form. Finally, let $J$ be the matrix formed from the final $n$ columns of $N$. Then $AJ=I_{n}$.

newcol.paragraphs: $A$ is nonsingular, there is a sequence of row operations that will convert $A$ into $I_{n}$. It is this same sequence of row operations that will convert $M$ into $N$, since having the identity matrix in the first $n$ columns of $N$ is sufficient to guarantee that $N$ is in reduced row-echelon form.

We have to be just a bit careful here about both what this theorem says and what it does not say. If $A$ is a nonsingular matrix, then we are guaranteed a matrix $B$ such that $AB=I_{n}$, and the proof gives us a process for constructing $B$. However, the definition of the inverse of a matrix requires that $BA=I_{n}$ also. So at this juncture we must compute the matrix product in the
order before we claim $B$ as the inverse of $A$. However, we will soon see that this is always the case.

statement.title: Matrix Inverse is Unique
Matrix Inverse is Unique
statement.paragraphs: Suppose the square matrix $A$ has an inverse. Then $A^{-1}$ is unique.

newcol.paragraphs: We will assume that $A$ has two inverses. The hypothesis tells there is at least one. Suppose then that $B$ and $C$ are both inverses for $A$. Then $AB=BA=I_{n}$ and $AC=CA=I_{n}$. Then we have, \begin{align*} \displaystyle B&\displaystyle=BI_{n} \\ &\displaystyle=B(AC) \\ &\displaystyle=(BA)C \\ &\displaystyle=I_{n}C \\ &\displaystyle=C \end{align*}

collapse.paragraphs: So we conclude that $B$ and $C$ are the same, and cannot be different. So any matrix that acts like an inverse, must be the inverse.

statement.paragraphs: Suppose that $A$ and $B$ are square matrices of size $n$. The product $AB$ is nonsingular if and only if $A$ and $B$ are both nonsingular.

newcol.paragraphs: ($\Rightarrow$) For this portion of the proof we will form the logically-equivalent contrapositive and prove that statement using two cases.

Case 2. Suppose $A$ is singular, and $B$ is not singular. Because $A$ is singular, there is a nonzero vector $\mathbf{y}$ that is a solution to $A\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}$. Now consider the linear system $B\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{y}$. Since $B$ is nonsingular, the system has a unique solution, which we will denote as $\mathbf{w}$. We first claim $\mathbf{w}$ is not the zero vector either. Assuming the opposite, suppose that $\mathbf{w}=\mathbf{0}$. Then \begin{align*} \displaystyle\mathbf{y}&\displaystyle=B\mathbf{w} \\ &\displaystyle=B\mathbf{0} \\ &\displaystyle=\mathbf{0} \\ \\ \displaystyle(AB)\mathbf{w}&\displaystyle=A(B\mathbf{w}) \\ &\displaystyle=A\mathbf{y} \\ &\displaystyle=\mathbf{0} \end{align*}
So $\mathbf{w}$ is a nonzero solution to $AB\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}$. Thus $AB$ is singular as desired. And this conclusion holds for both cases.

So $B\mathbf{x}$ is a solution to $A\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}$, and by the definition of a nonsingular matrix, we conclude that $B\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}$. Now, by an entirely similar argument, the nonsingularity of $B$ forces us to conclude that $\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}$. So the only solution to $AB\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}$ is the zero vector and we conclude that $AB$ is nonsingular.

newcol.paragraphs: The contrapositive of this entire result is equally interesting. It says that $A$ or $B$ (or both) is a singular matrix if and only if the product $AB$ is singular.

ref.title: Computing the Inverse of a Nonsingular Matrix

collapse.paragraphs: will fail as the first $n$ columns of $M$ will not row-reduce to the identity matrix. However, we can say a bit more. When $A$ is singular, then $A$ does not have an inverse (which is very different from saying that the procedure in Theorem

ref.label: CINM
ref.title: Computing the Inverse of a Nonsingular Matrix

collapse.paragraphs: fails to find an inverse). This may feel like we are splitting hairs, but it is important that we do not make unfounded assumptions. These observations motivate the next theorem.

statement.title: Nonsingularity is Invertibility
Nonsingularity is Invertibility
statement.paragraphs: Suppose that $A$ is a square matrix. Then $A$ is nonsingular if and only if $A$ is invertible.

newcol.paragraphs: ($\Leftarrow$) Since $A$ is invertible, we can write $I_{n}=AA^{-1}$. Notice that $I_{n}$ is nonsingular, so Theorem
implies that $A$ (and $A^{-1}$) is nonsingular.
($\Rightarrow$) Suppose now that $A$ is nonsingular. By Theorem

ref.label: CINM
ref.title: Computing the Inverse of a Nonsingular Matrix

newcol.paragraphs: we find $B$ so that $AB=I_{n}$. Then Theorem
tells us that $BA=I_{n}$. So $B$ is $A$’s inverse, and by construction, $A$ is invertible.
So for a square matrix, the properties of having an inverse and of having a trivial null space are one and the same. Cannot have one without the other.

statement.title: Nonsingular Matrix Equivalences Round 3
Nonsingular Matrix Equivalences, Round 3
statement.paragraphs: Suppose that $A$ is a square matrix of size $n$. The following are equivalent.

li.paragraphs: The null space of $A$ contains only the zero vector, ${\mathcal{N}}\!\left(A\right)=\{\mathbf{0}\}$.
The linear system $A\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}$ has a unique solution for every possible choice of $\mathbf{b}$.
The columns of $A$ are a linearly independent set.

newcol.paragraphs: In the case that $A$ is a nonsingular coefficient matrix of a system of equations, the inverse allows us to very quickly compute the unique solution, for any vector of constants.

statement.title: Solution with Nonsingular Coefficient Matrix
Solution with Nonsingular Coefficient Matrix
statement.paragraphs: Suppose that $A$ is nonsingular. Then the unique solution to $A\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}$ is $A^{-1}\mathbf{b}$.

collapse.paragraphs: Since $A\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}$ is true when we substitute $A^{-1}\mathbf{b}$ for $\mathbf{x}$, $A^{-1}\mathbf{b}$ is a (the!) solution to $A\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}$.

statement.paragraphs: Using the previous theorem, solve \begin{align*} \displaystyle x_{1}+x_{2}-x_{3}+4x_{4}&\displaystyle=1 \\ \displaystyle x_{1}-x_{2}+2x_{3}+3x_{4}&\displaystyle=2 \\ \displaystyle 2x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}+x_{4}&\displaystyle=0 \\ \displaystyle 2x_{1}+2x_{2}+2x_{3}-9x_{4}&\displaystyle=-1 \end{align*}

newcol.paragraphs: The matrix coefficient is \begin{align*} \displaystyle A=\left[\begin{array}[]{cccc}1&1&-1&4\\ 1&-1&2&3\\ 2&1&1&1\\ 2&2&2&-9\\ \end{array}\right]. \end{align*}

collapse.paragraphs: After some computations, \begin{align*} \displaystyle A^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}[]{cccc}-33&-22&45&-17\\ 35&23&-47&18\\ 25&17&-34&13\\ 6&4&-8&3\\ \end{array}\right]. \end{align*}

Then the solution of the system of linear equations is \begin{align*} \displaystyle \begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3}\\ x_{4}\end{bmatrix}=A^{-1}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 0\\ -1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}-60\\ 63\\ 46\\ 11\end{bmatrix}. \end{align*}
